The epic battle at the center of â€œWarcraftâ€ isnâ€™t the clash between humans and orcs. Thatâ€™s just what takes up roughly two hours of screen time. The true conflict comes from filmmakers trying to tell a story with soul and struggling against the inherent ridiculousness of the commodity theyâ€™re working with. It shouldnâ€™t take a mage to foresee that this pricey and preposterous adaptation of an online gaming phenomenon was preordained for artistic mediocrity. With little concern for all those already perplexed at the mention of orcs and mages, â€œWarcraftâ€ plunges headfirst into a fantasy realm teeming with mythical creatures, magical spells and exotically named characters and locations. Itâ€™s a take-it-or-leave-it approach likely to have most audience members opting for the latter, though devotees of the immersive role-playing source material may have an entirely different experience. If so, Universal will have to hope they storm the box office early and often. Otherwise the studio could be looking at one of the biggest duds of the summer. Thatâ€™s despite the noble effort of director Duncan Jones, who helmed the lower-budget sci-fi wonders â€œMoonâ€ and â€œSource Codeâ€ and labors mightily here to craft a solid emotional foundation in his script with Charles Leavitt. The â€œWarcraftâ€ games â€” which have radically declined in popularity from a high of 12 million regular users in 2010 to a recent low of close to 5 million (so low the company behind it no longer releases subscriber counts to the public) â€” were never meant to have the narrative depth of â€œThe Lord of the Rings,â€ or even â€œGame of Thrones.â€ But the film cribs freely from both of those sources anyway, as well as â€œStar Wars,â€ â€œDawn of the Planet of the Apes,â€ â€œAvatarâ€ and numerous other recent blockbusters. The orcs, a race of giant warrior beasts, flee their dying homeland of Draenor through a portal to the peaceful realm of Azeroth, where they wage a full-scale attack on unsuspecting humans for control of the land. Orc soldier Durotan (Toby Kebbell, like all orc players, working in performance capture) questions the brutal ways of his clansmen â€” led by warchief Blackhand (Clancy Brown) and power-hungry warlock Gulâ€™dan (Daniel Wu) â€” and believes a compromise without bloodshed is possible. His counterpart on the human side is Anduin Lothar (Travis Fimmel of TVâ€™s â€œVikingsâ€), a knight devoted to serving his benevolent king and queen (Dominic Cooper and Ruth Negga). Durotanâ€™s fierce mate Draka (Anna Galvin) delivers an adorable orc baby early on, and Lotharâ€™s son Callan (Burkely Duffield) is determined to impress his father on the battlefield. Those family ties are duly exploited for maximum melodramatic impact, as the dual protagonists rage and question and mourn and soulfully ponder the complexity that exists on two sides of any conflict. Ditto Garona (Paula Patton), a slave claiming to be half-orc, half-human, who makes her way through the portal and finds herself torn between the two sides. She quickly gets cozy with Lothar, but itâ€™s hard to take Patton or the character seriously with her â€œStar Trekâ€-alien-esque green skin and the oversized fangs jutting out from her jaw, looking like a last minute find in the Halloween store bargain bin, and making her sound like she has a mouth full of magic beans. And that goes to the root of the problems with â€œWarcraftâ€: itâ€™s an unwaveringly earnest film that never owns up to exactly how campy every character, every conflict and every new realm truly is. Ben Foster has another central role as reclusive wizard Medivh, a â€œGuardianâ€ of Azeroth who has been not so subtly dabbling in dark magic. Heâ€™s introduced sculpting a golem (surely youâ€™ll recall the old chestnut about Chekhovâ€™s golem), shirtless and wild-eyed, but it takes Lothar quite some time to piece together the warning signs. Medivh should be fun, but Fosterâ€™s deadpan turn is, like the movie around him, a drag. With its meticulously detailed realms built out primarily on soundstages and enhanced via CGI during extensive post-production, â€œWarcraftâ€ aims for fresh and eye-popping and yet ends up shopworn and rather tacky. It fits into a long line of visually audacious Hollywood gambles: In success you wind up with a sleeper that few see coming, like â€œ300â€ (or, if you strike the bullâ€™s-eye, a phenomenon like â€œAvatarâ€), but the ones that miss â€” â€œThe Spirit,â€ â€œSky Captain and the World of Tomorrow,â€ â€œSucker Punchâ€ â€” tend to tank hard. Boasting more thanÂ 2,000 visual effects shots, itâ€™s dispiriting to think about the time, energy, planning and precision that went into â€œWarcraftâ€ when the final product brings to mind those animated advertisements for iPhone app games. So good at making the most outlandish elements of his first two films seem completely credible, Jones canâ€™t find a way to get this cartoony spectacle to soar. His heartfelt approach to the material only underlines the silliness. Production designer Gavin Bocquet, costume designer Mayes C. Rubeo and visual effects supervisors Bill Westenhofer, Jeff White and Jason Smith lead the heavy lifting on the artisans side, since what the producers essentially purchased with the source material is a collection of locations, wardrobe, weapons, and spells. â€œWarcraftâ€ ends with a set-up for a sequel, but also the feeling that if this is what combat looks like, itâ€™s time to give peace a chance.

Ten years after game maker Blizzard Entertainment announced its intention to take the megahit multimedia property Warcraft to the big screen, it arrives in a striking blend of pricey practical and digital effects. As with many â€œhigh fantasyâ€ epics, once you get past the costumes and lingo, the abracadabra and inevitable elves, the movieâ€™s story is as simple as its visuals are elaborate. Beneath the richly textured layers of motion capture, animation and 3D modeling lie the basics: conflict, survival, family, loyalty. While the enormity of the undertaking is evident in every frame of the sci-fi medieval-ish action saga, director Duncan Jones manages, for the most part, to keep it from lumbering. With an emphasis on craft over war, the characters are front and center, and those that are partly digital creations are among its most memorable. They have heart. But if youâ€™ve never played Warcraft the game, can you care about Warcraft the movie? Given the ardent global following of the franchise, will it matter? For non-aficionados, the two-hour experience could be more concise, but itâ€™s no ordeal. Neither, though, is it consistently involving. If you havenâ€™t already invested in the self-serious mythology, it can feel borderline camp, if not downright dull â€” or both, as when an uncredited Glenn Close intones platitudes from on high about darkness and light. Yet thereâ€™s no question that itâ€™s a breakthrough in both storytelling and artistry for features based on video games. And compared with another medieval-ish tale, the soporific Hobbit trilogy, this international production is a fleet and nimble ride, likely to conquer overseas box offices and make a solid stand stateside. With three films on Jonesâ€™ rÃ©sumÃ©, the exponential growth of the budgets and fictional universes at his command is notable. The built-in muchness of the new material, along with its body-slamming battles (what the MPAA calls â€œextended sequences of intense fantasy violenceâ€), makes it a far cry from his minimalist Moon. In that film and Source Code, the trippy intersection of technology and human identity was Jonesâ€™ subject. Here itâ€™s his method, with leaps in CGI and motion capture on the order of Avatarâ€™s seven years ago, and just as dazzling in their artifice. The screenplay, credited to Jones and Charles Leavitt (Blood Diamond), tells the origin story of the war between humans and orcs, a race of green-blooded giants. The orcs have invaded Azeroth, a planet where humans, dwarves and other humanoids live in peace but with standing armies at the ready, led by the brave Anduin Lothar (Travis Fimmel), scarred in body and soul. As the bass rumble of voiceover by the orc chieftain Durotan (Toby Kebbell) explains, â€œOur world was dying, and I had to find my clan a new home.â€ Durotan is a fair and revered leader with exceptionally expressive eyes. Soon after the orcs arrive on Azeroth â€” through an otherworldly birth canal of sorts that prefigures the birth of Durotanâ€™s son â€” the chieftain becomes an insurgent against the orcsâ€™ de facto leader, the warlock Gulâ€™dan (Daniel Wu). Gul-dan practices a malignant brand of magic that spares no one, not even his loyal war chief,Â Blackhand (Clancy Brown), andÂ wreaks havoc throughout the story. But the nature of his powers is made hauntingly clear when he casually extracts the life force from one of his many prisoners, a masterfully realized bit of horror imagery. Along with his dauntless wife, Draka (Anna Galvin), and steadfast second-in-command, Orgrim (Rob Kazinsky), Durotan seeks an alliance with humans. Besides the warrior Lothar, Azerothâ€™s main players are the gallant King Llane Wrynn (Dominic Cooper, wisely underplaying); his dignified wife, Lady Taria (Ruth Negga, likewise); and the ultimate mage, Medivh (Ben Foster, definitely not underplaying). Like many a gifted channeller of powerful forces, Medivh is paying the price, and in the process providing the movieâ€™s most extravagantly hammy moments. The humongous golem heâ€™s sculpting in his isolated tower is the first red flag that heâ€™s several glyphs around the dark bend. A reluctant but curious young apprentice mage, Khadgar (Ben Schnetzer), stirs things up, to Medivhâ€™s deep dismay, and offers a touch of comic-sidekick relief. But itâ€™s the half-orc, half-human Garona (Paula Patton) who plays a pivotal role, and not just as a crucial go-between in the negotiations between Durotan and Lothar, who understandably falls for her. The movieâ€™s female characters are few, but theyâ€™re all formidable, and none more full-blooded than Pattonâ€™s turn as the tough Garona. Human-proportioned (her orc tusks are petite), sheâ€™s a survivor â€” of imprisonment and abuse born of intolerance for interspecies miscegenation. Rather than turn that into a lesson, the screenplay turns it into drama. In a story whose key strength is its interest in both sides of the human-orc war, Jones and cinematographer Simon Duggan strip things down in a few scenes that have the primal eloquence of classic Westerns: A trip on horseback over mountains becomes an occasion for campsite confessions; a secret meeting in a desolate canyon brings mutual suspicions and unilateral betrayals into the open. The balance between those sequences and the battles, with their brutal swordplay and thwacks of flesh and bone, wonâ€™t suit everyone, and the sections where you might zone out will depend on your taste. But the movie is character-driven every step of the way. Thatâ€™s why, even if the world created by Jones and his talented design collaborators, both old-school physical and cutting-edge digital, isnâ€™t seamlessly believable so much as staggeringly crafted, it casts a spell. Combining primitive textures (hides and sun-bleached bones) with the glowing whoosh of magical elements, Warcraft is a big-screen, 3D game that the viewer enters, to the martial beats of the elegantly ominous score by Ramin Djawadi (composer of the Game of Thrones theme). Its use of multiple cameras to film the motion capture performers in the same take as those playing human characters is one of the ways that itâ€™s new. And then thereâ€™s Durotanâ€™s eyes, and Garonaâ€™s grit. Dramatically and technically, Warcraft gives the concept of â€œhybridâ€ new punch.

Critics throw the term â€œsoulless corporate filmmakingâ€ around with abandon, but movies like â€œWarcraftâ€ really manage to redefine the term. A film adaptation of the hugely popular MMORPG (thatâ€™s Massively Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game), this latest video game adaptation ranks near the bottom of the deadly genre. Imagine â€œBattlefield Earthâ€ without the verve, or the unintentional comedy, and youâ€™ve got â€œWarcraft.â€ With his first two films, â€œMoonâ€ and â€œSource Code,â€ director Duncan Jones took high-concept science-fiction stories and spun them into taut tales that never lost sight of their characters or the toll of the extraordinary circumstances in which theyâ€™d been placed. This time around, sharing screenplay credit with Charles Leavitt (â€œIn the Heart of the Seaâ€) â€” based on story and characters by Chris Metzen â€” heâ€™s trying to wrestle with too many characters and locations and motivations and subplots, all in a movie thatâ€™s clearly intended to be but the first of many. The result is a monument to excess, both narratively and in the ubiquity of the visual effects. Unlike, say, â€œThe Jungle Book,â€ which was entirely artificial yet came off as completely organic, itâ€™s hard to lose sight of the green-screens here, especially when the warlike Orc characters, who boast some of the least expressive character design since the aliens in â€œJohn Carter,â€ stand next to the filmâ€™s human beings. Those two species wind up side-by-side when the Orc wizard Gulâ€™dan (voiced by Daniel Wu, â€œInto the Badlandsâ€) opens up a portal between their world and the magical kingdom of Azeroth, ruled over by King Llane and Lady Taria (Dominic Cooper and Ruth Negga, coincidentally also co-starring in â€œPreacherâ€). Lady Tariaâ€™s brother Anduin Lothar (Travis Fimmel, â€œMaggieâ€™s Planâ€) is one of Azerothâ€™s great warriors, although he wishes his young son werenâ€™t following in his footsteps. And then thereâ€™s Medivh (Ben Foster), a powerful wizard who is the Guardian of Azeroth, although young mage Khadgar (Ben Schnetzer, â€œPrideâ€) suspects that something is amiss amidst the Jedi â€¦ or rather, the Kirin Tor, the secret society of magic that protects the kingdom. On the other side, we have the mighty Durotan (voiced by Toby Kebbell, â€œFantastic Fourâ€), a deadly Orc warrior who is nonetheless a creature of principle, making his way through the portal with his pregnant wife Draka (Anna Galvin, â€œSmallvilleâ€), as well as human-Orc half-breed Garona (Paula Patton), whose alliances arenâ€™t necessarily fixed. Thereâ€™s a lot of running around and yelling and scheming and go-to-the-place-and-get-the-thing-ing, but none of it is particularly entertaining; like most movie versions of games, it will no doubt leave fans of the original wishing they were in charge. For the rest of us, thereâ€™s not even that sense of fun that comes from the sort of film that plays like a small child dumping all his action figures out on the living room carpet to battle each other. A good chunk of the disconnect can be attributed to cinematographer Simon Duggan (â€œThe Great Gatsbyâ€), who makes every location in â€œWarcraftâ€ â€” from the kingâ€™s stately castle to the Orc forests to Medivhâ€™s magical lair â€” look fairly artificial. Even if this was an attempt to emulate the online game, the big-screen results offer no visual pleasure. And the generically percussive action score composed by Ramin Djawadi (â€œGame of Thronesâ€) doesnâ€™t help much either. The cast seems mostly adrift, with only Schnetzer giving what might be considered an actual performance. The usually reliable Foster is reduced to gadding about like a prog-rock Jesus in a series of robes that make him look like heâ€™s posing for the side of someoneâ€™s van, and poor Paula Patton gets saddled with a sad pair of novelty-store fangs. (To her credit, she makes the green body makeup work; if the Marvel Cinematic Universe ever expands to include superhero-with-a-law-degree She-Hulk, weâ€™re looking at a real contender here.) â€œWarcraftâ€ promises, or threatens, sequels, but then so did â€œSuper Mario Bros.â€ And come to think of it, if forced to watch either of these video-game movies a second time, Iâ€™d probably vote for the plumbers.
